description: Practical slippage estimates and execution rules for options trading

execution_rules: If no fill in 60 seconds, improve by $0.01
Market orders acceptable for urgent exits

expected_slippage.limit_at_natural: Fills quickly but gives up edge

execution_rules: Start at mid, improve every 2 minutes
Never chase more than halfway to natural
If must trade, use patience orders over hours
Consider synthetic positions with liquid strikes
Never market order - you'll get destroyed

vertical_spreads.explanation: Two legs means double execution risk
rules: Always enter as single spread order, not legging
Improve by $0.02-0.05 if no fill in 2 minutes
Enter as single order when possible
If legging required, enter call spread and put spread separately
Front month usually more liquid than back month
Use spread orders, not individual legs
Wider bid-ask on back month - factor into pricing

market_open_9_30_10_00.recommendation: AVOID trading first 30 minutes unless urgent

market_close_15_00_16_00.recommendation: Okay for exits, avoid new positions

after_hours.recommendation: Options don't trade AH - plan accordingly

0_dte.gamma_risk: Maximum - small moves = big P&L swings
0_dte.recommendation: Only for experienced traders, expect 2x slippage

1_7_dte.liquidity: Good for ATM, poor for OTM
1_7_dte.recommendation: Most active trading range, watch time decay

45_plus_dte.recommendation: Good for LEAPS, expect patient execution

position_entry: Never use market orders for options
Don't chase more than 40% toward natural price
If too much slippage required, skip the trade
position_exit: Urgent exits may require hitting the bid (selling) or lifting the ask (buying)
Budget 2x normal slippage for panic exits
Close before expiration week for illiquid names
sizing_for_slippage: Factor slippage into position sizing: Real cost = premium + expected slippage
For illiquid options, slippage can be 5-10% of position value
Minimum position should justify transaction costs (slippage + commissions)

example.trade: Buy 10 contracts of AAPL $180 call @ $2.50 mid
example.break_even_impact: Stock needs to move $0.027 more to break even
